ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, I have a similar issue for competencies that are automatically met upon activity completion. I want to set the competency to "Competent" if a condition is met and "Not yet competent" if the condition is not met. For exemple, if I have a quiz activity and set the Activity completion to: - show activity complete when conditions met - student must receive a grade to complete the activity - require a passing grade And set the activity Competencies to: - select a course competency - Upon activity completion: Compete the competency When the student gets a passing grade in the quiz, the competency is marked as "Competent". But if the student does not get a passing grade, the competency is marked as "not rated". It seems that I can't generate both a "Competent" and "Not yet competent" rating for competencies ratings that can be automatically generated. Am I missing something? Thanks, Rob

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue with Learning Plan Monitor and unrated competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rob, Elsewhere in this forum, there was a discussion following the same basic question: can I use the competency rating in a similar way to the activity grading (and completion settings)? At this point, I would say the competencies approach can not be compared to the grading approach. With what Moodle presently provides for competencies, they're best used in an all-or-nothing way: you're either competent or you're not. Having said this, it might make sense to break the relevant competency (or competencies) down into more useful bits, adding multiple levels of competency to the test (a basic behavior, an average behavior, an above average behavior and an expert behavior). These ratings should not be in the same competency, but should be treated as separate ones. Then, breaking down the test into smaller units with a corresponding level of difficulty, will enable you to award 1 competency per test/quiz: basic test ==> basic competency average test ==> average competency above average test ==> above average competency expert test ==> expert competency As for the other issue of how to handle the not-rated-yet competencies: I think the recommendation would be to find a clearer way to have them displayed. In the regular studyplans overview window for a student, it displays a progress bar that will fill according to the number of competencies rated in the plan. Unrated competencies are and should be left out. Competencies rated as not competent, do show up in the list, but not in the progress bar. Condition to fill the bar is: competency is rated as competent. There is a lot of room for clarification and improvement in the way all this is displayed and how CBE is approached using Moodle, as you can see and read here... Hopefully this helps you in figuring out how to implement it all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency Breakdown Overall Report
ResponsesInList.Text: The best way to do this would be to see the competencies in the students' learning plans. However, by default only managers and teachers can view learning plans as they go beyond actual courses, since competencies can exist in more than one course. If you really need a regular teacher to see learning plans of their students, you could try using or adapting the Learning plan supervisor role.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enroll student into Learning Plan
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Baiju, First of all, there are 2 very different ways of working with competencies, as you already noted: - through student or cohort assigned learning plans - through competencies linked to a specific course and the activities in this course I am not aware of any ways of linking a learning plan to a student, other than creating a learning plan based on a template and then assigning it to a cohort or individual student. Since learning plans can contain competencies from multiple courses, I do not see any analogy with enrolling a student into a course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enroll student into Learning Plan
ResponsesInList.Text: If there are competencies linked to the course (and/or it's activities), these will show up in the Competencies list available to students. Here, a student will see to what degree he is competent, and to which activities the competencies are linked. A teacher can access the competencies breakdown report to see how each student's doing within the course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Required SQL for taxonomies

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Required SQL for taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: If the Level does not matter, then you can simply use LIKE here: WHERE cf.taxonomies LIKE '%skill%' If the Level matters, for instance you need to find skill at Level 3 specifically, then you would need to parse out the comma delimited string, probably using SUBSTRING and SUBSTRING_INDEX to find its place in the list.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help - Import Competency Format
ResponsesInList.Text: Your file is formatted wrong. You have headings of Grade, Strand,Standard #,Standard. You need to have Parent id number, Id number, Shortname, Description, Description format, Scale values, Scale configuration, Rule type (optional), Rule outcome (optional), Rule config (optional), Cross referenced competency id numbers, Exported id (optional), Is framework, Taxonomy. I've attached a sample Moodle one so that you can look at what's in it. You might try typing your first two or three competencies in by hand, export it the result after saving, then add the rest of your competencies into the exported csv file. Once that's all done, then try to import it.

Now it shows file format invalid. -- Cleared caches -- Again imported, Same error. -- deleted all the competency and children except frame work. successfully imported. -- now i entered only the competency and children ( No framework) it shows file format wrong --  and saved using text file as unicode text with tab select also same error Tested using 3.1 tried import in 3.2 also but same thing happen

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help - Import Competency Format
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Vivek, A few things: - on row 2, there should be a value for 'isframework' (1), as this row is used to define the Competency Framework. As row 1 contains all the headers, row 2 contains everything regarding the framework. - rows 3 and further should contain the actual structure of the framework (built according to the taxonomy you chose). These rows should NOT contain Scale Values, as these are defined at framework level. Nor should they contain Scale configuration (same applies as before). Rebuilding the file should work as following: in row 2, add general framework name, info and configuration (isframework = 1) in row 3 and 4 add SIL0K and SII0S, remove Scale Value and Scale config If you take the CEFR example from Moodle.net , you can follow that structure to build what you aim to achieve. // Edit 1 Which Competency Framework Importer do you use in Moodle 3.1? There are 2 (csv and rdf). A few screenshots would be helpful. // Edit 2 Make sure you build your file and then save it as a UTF8 csv. This is easy with Google Spreadsheet or Open/Libre Office, but is a heads up when working with an up to date version of MS Office.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello there, I have two issues with competencies that I hope have a workaround. #issue 1: Automated competency using competency rule can only move from 'not completed' to completed' and not backwards. I have a competency framework with a competency rule that e.g. 100 points need to be collected for completion of the competency. However, I decided I needed to change the points (e.g. happens when new comptencies are added), so the new total for completion is e.g. 120 points. However, I already received a "completed" status in my learning plan for achieving 100 points. The status does not automatically move back to 'not completed' because I now need 20 extra points. #issue 2: Manual set competency overrides automatic competency. No way to remove/reset manually set competency. I have set my competency to "completed" manually but now wish to undo that so that it will again look into my competency rules in the competency framework and automatically award competency when I fulfill the requirements. This appears to be impossible however, as it is not possible to change manual rating to "no rating" and manual rating appears to override automatic rating. Hope you can help me with this? If these two features indeed do not exist yet in Moodle, can i request them somewhere? Note: I am using Moodle 3.1. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Manual rating overrides automatic rating of competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Max, A lot of questions . I guess the thought behind this is as following: you're competent or you're not. Unlike the badge awarding system in Moodle (where you can modify criteria based on which the system will award badges or retract them), the competencies don't allow for this. There's no going back on being competent. I guess the same goes for the second question: once a student receives a competency rating, the only way to delete or undo it, is to remove the competency (framework) altogether. As for the requesting of features, this can be done in the Tracker . Make an account, find the Competencies bit under the Moodle project, rate or follow at least 4 tracker issues to prove you're a human being and you can request these features to be added. This is however subject to peer review and comments from the Moodle (dev) community, so there's no garantee the features will be added. IMHO , I doubt these features you described have any added value, but that's only my take on the subject.

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently, the dropdown to add a competency to an activity or resource is optional. However, I would like to make that mandatory if possible. Is there an easy way to do that?? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know if you can make competency a required field in any activity or resource. IMO that would lead to undesirable situations where your teachers/instructors will just pick a random competency to be done with it, or don't use any activities altogether. The way the competency frameworks are meant to be used, is through Learning Plans, that can be linked to cohorts or individual students in your LMS. At a course level, competencies might be useful to be linked to one activity, but not to others...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...
ResponsesInList.Text: I think you're right. The more I've been using the system, the more I've come to this same conclusion. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...
ResponsesInList.Text: Once competencies are more widely understood, it won't be unusual, I think, that students will ask why we are doing this or that activity if it is not linked to a competency.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes this is correct - and the course competencies page lists the activites each competency is linked to - so you can easily scan for competencies that are not linked to anything if that is important to you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using Moodle v3.2 and would like to edit the taxonomies available. The list of available levels is incomplete from my perspective and I would like to establish the following taxonomies under a competency: Skill: Capabilities aquired through practice. Knowledge : Understanding aquired through learning. Personal attributes : Inherent characteristics which are brought to the job. Behavior : The observable demonstration of some competency, skill, knowledge and personal attributes attributed to excellent performance. I also think that for some competencies 4 levels is inadequate and for others may be too much. I would like to suggest that the framework be more adjustable and editable. For example: Have a pull down so the user can indicate the number of taxonomy levels they require when creating a competency and also a way to edit the options available for the levels.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the feedback. The framework can actually have any number of levels. If you have less than 4 - the last taxonomy terms from the edit competency framework form will just not be used. If you create a framework and add more than 4 levels of competencies to it, then go back to the edit competency framework form - you will see you can choose taxonomy terms for the additional levels (no limit). If you have taxonomy terms that you want to use that are not in the list of predefined options - I recommend you edit the language strings for one of the existing terms that you don't want to use.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reply Damyon, What is the best way to edit the language strings for the existing terms?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Like this: https://docs.moodle.org/32/en/Language_customisation

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Damyon, I'll let you know how it works out for me. -Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Damyon, Thanks for your help. I was able to get the language customized as needed. But, of course, I have another question...Is there any way to link a competency to a course without using the learning plan?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes you can link competencies to a course without using a learning plan. This is how they work. Go to the course, then use the competencies link to see and add course competencies. Also it is better to ask each question in this forum as a new discussion with a new subject so other can find them later.

Thanks in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing competency frameworks csv failure
ResponsesInList.Text: I created https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-57292 to make sure we increase these limits when importing frameworks. In the meantime you could try increasing your max_execution_time in php.ini (if you have access to do that).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing competency frameworks csv failure
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, If you are not able to change the max_execution_time in php.ini, as mentioned by Damyon, you could try backing up a course on qa.moodle.net with your competencies, and then restore with competencies into your own site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing competency frameworks csv failure
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi AL, Damyon, Hopefully the max execution time solves the issue. It happens with competency framework csv files of approximately 80 kilobytes. I don't know whether this is too big for a generic moodle installation or not. The qa.moodle.net site also handled these files in a similar fashion, resulting in a bad gateway error. Edit ==> I increased both execution time (first to 0, then to 2 hrs) and memory limit (2GB), but to no avail.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing competency frameworks csv failure
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi AL and Damyon, Apparently, I solved the problem by removing all the lines in my csv that didn't have an ID number linked to it. Somehow that's where it goes wrong, because since solving this, I've been able to upload competency frameworks without a hitch. The plugin could however do with a more suitable error page when the imported csv file ends up not being valid because of such things. An HTTP 500, Bad Gateway or connection timed out page from the browser does not tell the developer where to correct the file. For people constructing these frameworks, it's very tempting to have these 'comment' lines in the document while building, in order to know how it is structured.

ResponsesInList.Title: Competency rule and cross-referenced competency
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Thank you in advance Here are the 2 problems which are little difficult to understand 1. In competency rule how a student get these points (from where these points are given) . 2. What is the benefit of using cross referenced competency here. It just shown in the cross referenced area. What is its proper use please explain in detail ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency rule and cross-referenced competency
ResponsesInList.Text: I asked myself the same question and still dont have an answer... I think both features don't make sense by now and they are just integrated for some future implementations

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency rule and cross-referenced competency
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello Arun, Points in competency rules is just a way to trigger an action on a parent competency (Mark as complete, attach evidence or recommend) depending on rules on the child competencies. Points give you the possibility to add some more or less weight to child competencies on completing the parent one (Some maybe more important competencies ). In your example, giving equal points to all child competencies and say they are all required would do the same thing as choosing the option "when all children are completed". Like I said in a previous post ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=336350 ), "Cross-referencing competencies do nothing more than showing competencies
related to one another. I think the purpose is to make it easier for
students who would build their own plan to find competencies to add". There is not other logic or mechanism here. Regards, Jean-Philippe

But then I edit the Competency framework and modify the erroneous scale default value... the evaluation does not change for this student. He keep the old values. Is it  a way to force the re-evaluation of the competencies and give the new default value to all students whose have been evaluated before the modification ? Sure, I can set up a SQL request and update the table competency_usercomp, field grade from 2 to 3 for example, but this would be better if we had  that option in Moodle ;>)) It may be then a cron update...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to propagate a modification of the Competency frameworks scale to competencies yet validated ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jean, Unfortunately I think the only option right now would be to write a custom script to do that. But I think an issue in the tracker could be created as it would be a good improvement to CBE. Regards, Jean-Philippe

For instance, a competency in Minnesota 4th grade Science is " 4.2.3.2.3, Demonstrate how an electric current can produce a magnetic force. For example: Construct an electromagnet to pick up paperclips." That competency (Minnesota calls it a benchmark) is one competency in the group of standards, named, 'Energy can be transformed within a system or transferred to other systems or the environment.' The group that that standard is in is called "Energy" which is a group in the larger group, Physical Science, which is in the larger group Mn 4th Grade Science Standards. I would like to use an off line submission of an Assignment activity that includes a rubric to determine whether or not the student(s) have achieved mastery of that competency. I would likely have a comprehension quiz and another simple assignment on which students would need to earn a certain grade and complete before they attempted the Construct an electromagnet project. As the Director of Elementary Science (theoretically) for a school district that includes 45 elementary schools that each have on average 3 classes of 4th graders, I want to run a report on that competency by class, by building and for the whole district. I would also like to be able to drill down and view the artifact submitted by each student, and the completed rubric with teacher comments, in fulfillment of this competency. There are twenty other 'benchmarks' in 4th Grade Science with hierarchical groupings at each of the above levels. I will also like to run reports on aggregations of those 'scores' by all of the above. How do I set-up reports like that? Here's a pdf of all of the Minnesota K12 Science Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in Science (2009)

ResponsesInList.Title: Managing business competencies with Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I'm looking for the best way to implement something like business competencies and periodic assessment in Moodle. Lets say I have 5 main competencies with sub competencies Competency 1 subcomp 1 subcomp 2 etc. Competency 2 Competency 3 Competency 4 Competency 5 Some platform-wide manager can grade sub competencies (preferably maybe define some of the description grades like "You can easily communicate in english in writing and talking" or "Your talking is a little poor and writing is good" so he can easily use it to grade every user in the same way - and every description would have its own points, in percents lets say), and then from the sub competencies overall grade for competency is calculated (normal arithmetic average would be ok). I know I can open the grade book, add new category "Competency 1" and insert inside that category sub competencies, then grade it and I can have my grade for the competency from them. But is this platform wide or only  inside the course? Is it a proper way to use it, or maybe better would be outcomes or competencies? How to proper configure scales, if they are needed? And in the farer perspective - how to merge it with course completion or grade depending on the quiz result? I know moodle would grant me the best possible solution, but as always - way to achieve it is painful So I hope you can share yours experience! Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Managing business competencies with Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: I think that Competencies in Moodle 3.1 is exactly what you need, because : 1) Grades are only in the course (not platform wide), and it would be difficult to agregate many grades from many courses in a synthesis way to say for example "This student gets 70% of  the skills". 2) Outcomes are fine, you can associate a scale to each outcome, use Assignment for evaluation and see them in the gradebook, but like grades, outcomes are not platform wide. Competencies in Moodle 3.1 are a very powerful tool and we need changing a bit our teaching habits but : - Competency Frameword supports hierarchy between skills - Different Scales may be associated to different Competencies - Learning plans may be associated to individual users or to cohort - Competencies are platform wide and, better, category wide - Competencies may be evaluated through activities By the way you may transform your Outcomes list and scales to a competency framework. PS: Excuse my poor english...

ResponsesInList.Title: Cannot link courses to competency
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, Have set competency framework + compenties, but if i would like course activity link to course compenties th field is empty and cannot make a selection. Anyone suggestions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Cannot link courses to competency
ResponsesInList.Text: Righto, found it:  Course administration > Course competencies. Have to select framework/competencies first before within activities you can select competencies!

ResponsesInList.Title: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm a little bit confused about the new competency feature that is introduced with Moodle 3.1. Can someone please enlighten how it is different from outcomes? As it is stated in MoodleDocs for Outcomes : Outcomes are specific descriptions of what a student has demonstrated and understood at the completion of an activity or course. Each outcome is rated by some sort of scale. Other terms for outcomes are Competencies and Goals.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings Martin - I agree - I was just about to post this - so thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: I also agree about outcomes and competencies being confusing! In Moodle, there is a site administration setting called 'Enable outcomes' and in 3.1, the description of this setting has been changed to 'If enabled, grade items may be graded using one or more scales tied to outcome statements.' Thus, outcomes in Moodle are to do with grading only. There is also a site administration setting in 3.1 called 'Enable competencies', the description of which is 'Competencies allow users to be assessed according to learning plans.' The documentation Competencies provides a fuller explanation, mentioning competency frameworks too. Thus, competencies in Moodle 3.1 are a lot more complex than outcomes!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: As always Helen - excellent clear description. May I please add that we may need both Competencies and outcomes in the gradebook. Our ministry looks very closely at the "outcomes of our competencies" and we need a method in the course to assess how many students achieved the competency and report that in our Ministry reports. We are now very integrated to the Moodle gradebook and in my opinion in the short time I spent in working through the competency framework - I would love to be able to attach it to the graded item and to evaluate the results through the gradebook. I know there is a work around but I would like to encourage the developers to add them to the gradebook for adding it to a graded item and the category. Thank you again, Nancy K.

ResponsesInList.Title: CBE import plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I am working on implementing CBE on my moodle Moodle 3.1rc2 (Build: 20160520). I would like to import competency framework from cvs text file. Could u please let me know what is the right plugin to use and how to git install it. Best regards kal

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CBE import plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Khaled, There is a plugin for importing CBE frameworks, but so far as I know it is not yet in the Moodle download s area. You can get it anyway from github at https://github.com/damyon/moodle-tool_lpimportcsv It needs to be installed in yourmoodle/admin/tool and once installation is completed, you will have an Import and Export link added under Competencies. Works nicely and will let you match your csv file columns to the one used by Moodle CBE frameworks, if they are not the same already.
